text: Thank you so much for the applause,
because I'm here as an intervention,

and I don't expect that I'll
get applause afterwards.
(audience laughs)
I am Sandra Finley,

and I'm President and CEO of
the League of Black Women.

The organization was founded
in 1970 for one purpose
and that is to chart, support, research,

and advocate for the
leadership opportunity
for Black women in America.

And so speaking for the
Black women in America,
which I can do,

because I'm CEO of the
League of Black Women,
(audience laughs)
I want simply to say this thing,
and that is we need for you
and all of those who you have influence on
to quit referring to us as people of color
when we done told you we Black, all right?
You have no clear idea of the stress

and the assault on our
ears and on our spirits

when we have to translate
what you probably mean
when you say people of color

when we know that we
done told you we Black.
I have been in conversations with folk,
and they have looked at me and said,

"Well, Sandra, what do you
think as a woman of color?"
And I said, "I done told you, I'm Black."
(audience laughs)
"Yeah, yeah, yeah, I know."

But speaking for people of
color, which I cannot do,
as a matter of fact, nobody can.
Nobody really knows who that is, clearly.

I remember the first time
it came up in conversation.

I was on the phone with a
guy talking about something

and he said, "Blah, blah,
blah, people of color."
And I asked, "What color?"
And then he started to list the groups

that he was actually
interested in addressing,
and then he got tired.
He said, "It's just too many."
There was too many to be bothered
with actually being specific.
One of the things that I admire
about the LGBTQ mission
and movement is the precision of it.

When the folk who are
part of the community
determined to add another letter,
you better learn it.
We insist on it.
(laughs)

And if we can afford that
kind of respect to any group,
why not our group?
So I took a look at it.
What made this society think it was okay
to go and go fluid on us?

So I know that Black Power
is a phrase that you know,
and I have lived long enough in the world
to go through several attempts
to seize the power of our nomenclature,
impose inappropriate racial
and cultural identity on my people.
When I was born in 1950,
generally the conversation around

who we might be as a community
was colored, colored.

And then as I grew maybe
another 10 years or so,
then the effort to say who we were
was more specifically Negro.
Long emphasis on the long E, all right?

And then as I got
somewhere into my maturity
and my high school years and whatever,
then we said I'm Black and I'm proud
and we meant it.
We named ourselves and I got big hair

and didn't have to sit
between my mama's legs
and have a straightening comb go no more.
We just let it all happen.
Now I lived most of my adult life

with the affirmative title
of being a Black woman.
I knew who I was.
The world knew who I was, it worked,

and it also spoke about power,
and community, and culture.

Achievement, ambition,
and all those things.

That's what comes in
with the title of Black.

Of color says nothing
about those kinds of things

that you need to know coming
through the door with me
when I walk in.
Nothing, you get no information.
I'm not well-represented at all.
Just to kind of get ready for this chat,
I dug out a copy of my birth certificate.

It says here that my name
is Sandra Jean Killingsworth
and then I married Eddie,
but that's later on.

And then it says my parents
are Cleave Lee Killingsworth,
and it says he's a Negro right here.

And it says that my mama
was Lee Ethel Hunter
and then she's a Negro as well.
Presumably they birthed out a Negro baby
for the times that we were in.

So the self-determination
by a people to name itself
and then say what that stands for
is everything, is everything.
And I need to let you all know,
because you all are influencers.
You are educators, you are advocates.

When you take a position on
something, other people listen.
So, I need for you to hear me say this.

If you keep calling my
people people of color,
I'm coming for you.
(audience laughs)
They got your names on the list.
I know where to find you.
Robin gave it to us.
We can find that out.

But there are times when
communities make evolutions

or changes to who they
want to be known as,

and here's how it looks
when it's done right.
In December 1988 at a conference,

a news conference at the
Hyatt Regency in Chicago
where 75 leaders of Black groups,

Black groups met to discuss
a national Black agenda,

Reverend Jesse Jackson announced
that members of their race,

our race, preferred to be
called African Americans.

Now his rationale for
that was that he felt

that we needed to be
connected to our continent
and African American would do that.

And generally, according
to this news report,
most of the people who were there

representing other organizations
like mine, would've been,
thought that was a good idea.
It was interesting enough,
African American didn't replace Black.
It simply edified more about it.

Kind of like your last
name if it comes up.

So I'd be Sandra Jean
Killingsworth Finley,

African American, but Black
first under all of that.
That would be all of that.
But it usually takes a convening
of the leadership of the people
(gong rings)

to determine what's in the
best interest of the people
and that didn't happen to my knowledge.

If the meeting happened
that said that Black people
are going to be people of color,
I wasn't invited to that meeting at all.
And therefore we're not absolutely clear
where it came from.
Now there are different reports
of somebody had a meeting here

and thought it was a
good idea or whatever,
but the fact is we don't know two things.
(gong rings)

We don't know where
people of color came from,

and we don't know where
exactly where COVID came from,

but they're both insidious
and messing with folk.

So there's been a gong here
I was supposed to hear.
(audience laughs)

I simply want you to know
you can do better than this.
You can be better than this,

and you shouldn't put it
on us to be comfortable

or find a way like
wearing a crinoline skirt

in an effort to endure the
discomfort that it takes

for us to have to hear
you say people of color.
Don't do it anymore.
You can do this, thank you.
(audience applauds)
